Unsignalized Intersection Level of Service Definitions Based on Delay ........................................ 7
Near-Term Plus Project Intersection Levels of Service ............................................................... 34
P a g e | i i
This report presents the results of the traffic impact analysis (TIA) for the Town of Atherton’s Civic Center
Master Plan (project). The Civic Center is located on Dinkelspiel Station Lane between Fair Oaks Lane and
Maple Avenue, in the Town of Atherton, California. The project would demolish approximately 20,200 square
feet of building space, including the Town Administration building, Police Department, Police Garage, Permit
Center, Library, storage facility, and Public Works offices and construct a new 25,500-square foot Town
Administration building, a 1,300-square foot Police ancillary building, and a 9,000-square foot library. Existing
buildings to be retained include the 1,700-square foot Council Chambers (Town Hall) and the 2,000-square
The Master Plan project would reconfigure Ashfield Road and Dinkelspiel Station Lane around the new Civic
Center. Dinkelspiel Station Lane would no longer connect directly to Fair Oaks Lane. Instead, Dinkelspiel
Station Lane would terminate at Ashfield Road, which would be realigned and extended to intersect with Fair
Oaks Lane directly opposite from Fair Oaks Court. The intersection of Fair Oaks Lane and Ashfield Road
would be stop controlled on the north (Fair Oaks Court) and south (Ashfield Road) approaches.
The proposed change in the roadway network would eliminate the Dinkelspiel Station Lane/Fair Oaks Lane
intersection, and thus the existing stop sign on eastbound Fair Oaks at Dinkelspiel Station could be
eliminated. However, due to the restricted sight distance at the Fair Oaks/Lloyden intersection, it is
recommended that the existing stop sign on eastbound Fair Oaks Lane be moved from its current location at
Dinkelspiel Station to the eastbound Fair Oaks approach at Lloyden Drive. With the recommended stop
control on the eastbound approach, traffic stopped on southbound Lloyden Drive would be able to see all
opposing traffic in both directions before proceeding.
The new Civic Center would result in an increase in library and administrative building space. However, the
Town is not expected to increase administrative staff in the future or provide new administrative services at
the Civic Center. Therefore, the trip generation associated with the administrative uses at the new Civic
Center (including the Town Administration, Building, Planning, Police, and Public Works Departments) are
expected to be the same as under existing conditions. Thus, the net new project trips reflect an increase only
in library trips resulting from an increase in library space from 5,058 square feet under existing conditions to
the proposed 9,000 square feet. The additional building space will enable the library to increase their
collection and provide additional services not present at the existing library. Furthermore, the proposed library
may generate traffic at a higher rate per square foot than the existing library due to the attractiveness of the
P a g e | i i i
A trip generation survey was conducted to quantify the trips generated by the existing library. The library did
not generate any trips during the AM peak hour on the day of the survey. During the PM peak hour, the
existing library generated 11 vehicle trips (4 inbound and 7 outbound). The observed trip rates are less than
the average library trip rates published in the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation, 9
Edition. To be conservative, the trips generated by the new library were estimated using the ITE library trip
rates. Trips generated by the existing library were subtracted from the trip estimates for the proposed library
to estimate the net new project trips. After applying the trip credit, the proposed library is estimated to
generate a net increase of 421 daily vehicle trips including 9 AM peak-hour trips (6 inbound and 3 outbound)
and 55 PM peak-hour trips (28 inbound and 27 outbound).
Table ES-1 summarizes the results of the peak-hour intersection level of service analysis under the following
scenarios: existing, existing plus project, near-term, and near-term plus project.
Under all scenarios, the following two study intersections are expected to operate at a poor level of service:
El Camino Real and Ashfield Road: LOS F on both stop-controlled approaches (eastbound and
westbound) in both the AM and PM peak hours.
El Camino Real and Maple Avenue: LOS F on the eastbound stop-controlled approach in the AM
peak hour and the westbound stop-controlled approach in the PM peak hour.
The remaining study intersections are expected to operate at LOS C or better during both the AM and PM
The peak-hour traffic volumes at the El Camino Real/Ashfield Road or El Camino Real/Maple Avenue
intersections would not warrant signalization under any scenario. Thus, signalization of these study
At the El Camino Real/Ashfield Road intersection, the project is expected to cause a slight decrease in traffic
volume because some of the existing trips that currently access the library via Ashfield Road would likely shift
to Maple Avenue. Therefore, the project impact on traffic operations at this intersection would be less than
At the El Camino Real/Maple Avenue intersection, the project is expected to add one trip in the AM peak hour
and 8 trips in the PM peak hour to the westbound left-turn movement from Maple Avenue to southbound El
Camino Real. Field observations and the intersection level of service analysis show that the heavy volume of
traffic on El Camino Real leaves few gaps in traffic large enough to accommodate left turns from the stop-
controlled Maple Avenue approaches. As a result, the small increase in traffic associated with the project
would cause the average delay on the westbound stop-controlled approach to increase by more than four
seconds during the PM peak hour. Therefore, the project is considered to have a significant impact at this
intersection. The impact could be satisfactorily mitigated by implementation of one or both of the following
Prohibit Left Turns. The Town of Atherton may choose to prohibit left turns from westbound Maple
Avenue to southbound El Camino Real. With the turn restriction, the westbound stop-controlled
approach would operate at LOS B during the PM peak hour. The turn restriction could be put in effect
only during certain hours (e.g. 5:00 – 7:00 PM ) through appropriate signage or all day by signage
and a raised median that would physically prevent left-turns and through movements from Maple
Avenue. Restricting left turns only during peak hours would retain full access during other times when
traffic volumes and delay are lower. However, it would be difficult to enforce the part-time turn
restriction since there would not be a physical barrier preventing vehicles from turning left. Also, it
should be noted that the Town’s General Plan states that street lights and signs shall be kept to a
minimum (Policy 2.426). Therefore, the Town may choose to consider alternative mitigation
Public Education. While the traffic analysis assumes that trips to and from the Civic Center uses will
travel via the most direct routes, it is likely that many Civic Center drivers seeking to head south on El
P a g e | i v
Camino Real may choose to travel through the signalized Fair Oaks/El Camino intersection in order
to avoid the difficulty of turning left onto El Camino Real from Maple Avenue based on prior
experience at this location or other unsignalized intersections on El Camino Real. The self-selection
of Fair Oaks Avenue may reduce the project impact at the Maple/El Camino intersection below that
shown in Table ES-1. The Town of Atherton may further reduce the project’s impact at the Maple/El
Camino intersection through the use of a public education campaign to advise motorists traveling
between the Civic Center and El Camino Real to use Fair Oaks Lane. Notices may be sent to local
residents on Maple Avenue and Civic Center employees, and posted for public view at various
locations within the Civic Center including the Atherton Library.
Roadway segment traffic volumes were evaluated for Fair Oaks Lane, Ashfield Road, and Maple Avenue
between El Camino Real and Dinkelspiel Lane. The analysis results indicate that roadway segment traffic
volumes under all scenarios would be within the typical volume range established by the Town.
The project would reconfigure the Civic Center circulation network to safely accommodate all transportation
modes. In addition to the local street network, the Civic Center would include a network of fully accessible
paths for pedestrians and bicyclists. The network would also link existing and proposed open spaces to
existing buildings, such as the Town Hall and Caltrain Station.
As shown in the Master Plan, Dinkelspiel Station Lane would remain the main north/south connection through
the Civic Center area linking Fair Oaks Lane to the north and Maple Street to the south. Additionally, Ashfield
Road would continue to function as the western gateway connecting to both El Camino Real and Fair Oaks
Lane. Near the northern edge of the site, Dinkelspiel Station Lane would curve to the west and intersect with
Ashfield Road just south of Fair Oaks Lane. Two-way stop control is recommended with a stop sign on
Dinkelspiel Station Lane and no control on Ashfield Road. Although this intersection would be only about 60
feet south of the Fair Oaks/Ashfield intersection, the traffic volumes on Ashfield Road are projected to remain
rather low such that, except for very rare occurrences, no more than a single vehicle would be stopped at
either intersection. Therefore, traffic is not expected to back up from one intersection through the next.
Ninety-degree parking spaces are proposed at various locations along Dinkelspiel Station Lane and Ashfield
Road. The traffic volumes and vehicle speeds on these streets are expected to be low such that parking
maneuvers would not pose a hazard or significantly disrupt traffic. In addition, a small off-street parking area
is shown immediately north of the proposed Town Administration Building. This lot would have 90-degree
parking on both sides of a dead end aisle. There appears to be sufficient space at the end of the parking aisle
to allow vehicles to turn around when the lot is full. Since it would be difficult to determine if any spaces were
available before turning into the lot, it is recommended that these spaces be reserved for staff parking.
The Civic Center Master Plan contains conceptual level drawings that lack the detail required for a thorough
review of specific design features. In order to provide a circulation network that would safely accommodate
automobiles, pedestrians, and bicyclists, it’s recommended that the final design incorporate the following
Maintain minimum roadway pavement width to reduce vehicle travel speeds within the project site.
Provide adequate sight distance at intersections and roadway curves within the Civic Center area to
ensure safe access for all travel modes.
Provide adequate lighting along pedestrian/bicycle paths within the Civic Center area.
Street widths and radii of curvature should allow for the movement of garbage trucks, delivery
vehicles, fire trucks and other emergency vehicles.

text.b: Potential Impacts on Bicycle, Pedestrian, and Transit Facilities

page.text: Most public roadways in the Town are suitable for use by bicyclists and pedestrians. Additionally, the project
would provide a circulation network to safely accommodate all transportation modes, including bicycle and
pedestrian travel within the Civic Center area. Therefore, although the new library may increase bicyclists and
pedestrians accessing the Civic Center, they should be able to ride/walk on access streets in the project
vicinity without major safety concerns. For streets within the Civic Center area, implementation of the
recommendations listed in the previous section will ensure safe on-site circulation for bicyclists and
The Town of Atherton’s Pedestrian and Bicycle Master Plan, adopted in November 2014, shows that several
streets within the study area, including Fair Oaks Lane, Watkins Avenue, and Dinkelspiel Station Lane, are to
be designated as Class III bike routes. Because the project would reconfigure Dinkelspiel Station Lane
through the Civic Center, the roadway design should implement the recommended bike route along
Dinkelspiel Station Lane with appropriate cross-section design, signage, and pavement markings to ensure
consistency with the Pedestrian and Bicycle Master Plan.
The proposed Civic Center would continue to be served by the existing SamTrans bus routes and Caltrain.
No change in service is expected as a result of the project. The project is expected to have an insignificant
impact on the existing transit ridership levels.
The existing Civic Center includes approximately 210 parking spaces, including 96 spaces at the Atherton
Caltrain Station, 52 spaces for the Administration Building/Police/Post Office, 20 spaces for the Permit
Center, 9 spaces in the Public Works Corporation Yard, and 33 spaces for the Library. The Master Plan
project would reduce the parking supply by approximately 91 spaces leaving a total of 119 spaces at buildout,
including 33 spaces for Caltrain parking, 63 spaces for Civic Center uses, 19 spaces for secure police
parking, and 4 spaces in the Public Works Corporation Yard.
In order to estimate the parking demand for the new Civic Center, a parking occupancy survey was conducted
to quantify the parking demand generated by the existing Civic Center uses. The maximum parking demand
observed was 63 vehicles on a weekday and 49 vehicles on a Saturday. For the library, the maximum parking
demand observed was 13 vehicles on the weekday and 26 vehicles on the Saturday, when there was a
presentation held during the survey period.
The Town is not expected to increase administrative employees in the future or provide new administrative
services at the Civic Center. Therefore, the parking demand for these uses is expected to remain unchanged.
The new library is the only use that may generate an increase in parking demand above the current parking
occupancy. It is estimated that the new library would generate a peak parking demand of 23 vehicles on
Since Caltrain service at the Atherton station is currently limited to weekends only, the Caltrain parking
spaces are mostly unused. However, the planned Caltrain Electrification Project would reintroduce weekday
service with 54 trains projected to stop in Atherton each day. With the Electrification Project, it is estimated
that Caltrain riders would occupy as many as 28 parking spaces at the Atherton Civic Center in the year 2020
(Peninsula Corridor Electrification Project EIR, February 2014). The dedicated Caltrain parking proposed in
the Civic Center Master Plan (33 spaces) would be adequate to accommodate the projected ridership at the
The overall peak Civic Center parking demand with the new library and the planned Caltrain service is
estimated to be 95 vehicles on weekdays and 86 vehicles on weekends, which is lower than the proposed
parking supply of 119 spaces. Therefore, the project would provide a sufficient parking supply to meet the
projected overall demand. However, it should be noted that the project proposes only 4 parking spaces for the
Public Works Corporation Yard while the parking occupancy survey showed as many as 7 vehicles parked in
the Corporation Yard on a weekday. Any parking overflow in this area could be accommodated by the

Overall weighted average control delay (seconds per vehicle) is reported for signalized intersections.
Worst stop-controlled approach delay (seconds per vehicle) is reported for two-way stop-controlled intersections.
Intersection would not exist with the proposed project.
For scenarios with the proposed project, the level of service reflects the recommended stop control on EB and SB legs.
With mitigation (prohibit left turn or public education to divert left-turn traffic from Maple), the intersection would operate at LOS B.
Bold indicates a substandard level of service.
This report presents the results of the traffic impact analysis (TIA) for the Town of Atherton’s Civic Center
Master Plan (project). The Civic Center is located on Dinkelspiel Station Lane between Fair Oaks Lane and
Maple Avenue, in the Town of Atherton, California. The project would demolish approximately 20,200 square
feet of building space, including the Town Administration building, Police Department, Police Garage, Permit
Center, Library, storage facility, and Public Works offices and construct a new 25,500-square foot Town
Administration building, a 1,300-square foot Police ancillary building, and a 9,000-square foot library. Existing
buildings to be retained include the 1,700-square foot Council Chambers (Town Hall) and the 2,000-square
foot Public Works corporation yard. Additionally, the project includes the reconfiguration of Ashfield Road and
Dinkelspiel Station Lane around the new Civic Center.
The project site location and the surrounding study area are shown on Figure 1. The existing site plan is
shown on Figure 2 and the proposed site plan is shown on Figure 3.
The purpose of the traffic study is to satisfy the requirements of the Town of Atherton, the City/County
Association of Governments of San Mateo County (C/CAG) and the California Environmental Quality Act
(CEQA). Since it is estimated that the project would generate fewer than 100 peak hour vehicle trips on San
Mateo County Congestion Management Program (CMP) facilities, an analysis of impacts on state routes and
routes of regional significance in accordance with the C/CAG’s CMP guidelines are not required.
The traffic study analyzed the traffic impacts of the project on seven key intersections in the vicinity of the
project site during the weekday AM and PM peak commute hours of traffic (7:00–9:00 AM and 5:00–7:00 PM,
respectively). The study intersections were selected in consultation with Town staff and include those
intersections which provide primary access to the existing library. The study intersections are identified below
1. El Camino Real (SR 82) and Fair Oaks Lane/Atherton Avenue
2. Fair Oaks Court/Ashfield Road (future) and Fair Oaks Lane
3. Dinkelspiel Station Lane and Fair Oaks Lane (existing only)
4. Lloyden Drive and Fair Oaks Lane
5. El Camino Real (SR 82) and Ashfield Road
6. El Camino Real (SR 82) and Maple Avenue
7. Dinkelspiel Station Lane and Watkins Avenue
The intersection of Dinkelspiel Station Lane and Fair Oaks Lane was analyzed under existing conditions only
because the project would reconfigure the roadways within the Civic Center such that Dinkelspiel Station
Lane would not directly connect to Fair Oaks Lane (Figure 3).
In addition, the study includes an analysis of daily traffic volumes on the following roadway segments:
1. Fair Oaks Lane between El Camino Real and Dinkelspiel Station Lane
2. Ashfield Road between El Camino Real and Dinkelspiel Station Lane
3. Maple Avenue between El Camino Real and Dinkelspiel Station Lane
Traffic conditions were evaluated for the following scenarios:
Scenario 1: Existing Conditions. Existing conditions were represented by existing traffic volumes on the
existing roadway network. Existing traffic volumes were obtained from recent traffic counts
Scenario 2: Existing Plus Project Conditions. Existing plus project conditions reflect the projected traffic
volumes and proposed roadway network with implementation of the project. Existing plus
project traffic volumes were estimated by adding to existing traffic volumes the trips
associated with the proposed Civic Center project. Existing plus project conditions were
evaluated relative to existing conditions in order to determine potential project impacts.
Scenario 3: Near-Term Conditions. Near-term conditions reflect future traffic volumes on the existing
roadway network. Near-term traffic volumes were estimated by adding to existing traffic
volumes the projected volumes from approved but not yet constructed developments in the
Scenario 4: Near-Term Conditions Plus Project Conditions. Near-term plus project conditions reflect
the future traffic volumes and roadway network with implementation of the project. Near-
term plus project traffic volumes were estimated by adding to near-term traffic volumes the
trips associated with the proposed Civic Center project. Near-term plus project conditions
were evaluated relative to near-term conditions in order to determine potential project
This section describes the methods used to determine the traffic conditions for each scenario described
above. It includes descriptions of the data requirements, the analysis methodologies, and the applicable level
The data required for the analysis were obtained from field observations, new traffic counts, previous traffic
studies, and the Town of Atherton. The following data were collected from these sources:
Existing intersection peak-hour volumes and roadway daily volumes,
Trip generation by approved but not yet completed projects,
Trip generation at the existing library, and
Parking generation at the existing library.
Traffic conditions at the study intersections were evaluated using level of service (LOS). Level of Service is a
qualitative description of operating conditions ranging from LOS A, or free-flow conditions with little or no
delay, to LOS F, or jammed conditions with excessive delays.
This study utilizes TRAFFIX software to determine intersection level of service. The TRAFFIX software is
based on the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) methodology for signalized and unsignalized
intersections. This method evaluates intersection operations on the basis of average control delay time for all
vehicles at the intersection. This average delay can then be correlated to a level of service. Table 1 presents
the level of service definitions for signalized intersections. The level of service definitions for unsignalized
intersections is shown in Table 2. Note that for unsignalized intersections under two-way stop control, the
level of service is reported for the worst approach.
In addition to the level of service evaluation, a supplemental assessment of the need for signalization was
conducted for unsignalized intersections. This assessment was made on the basis of signal warrant criteria
adopted by Caltrans. For this study, the need for signalization is assessed on the basis of the operating
conditions at the intersections (i.e., level of service) and on the peak-hour volume signal warrant – warrant #3
– described in the 2014 California Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). This method
provides an indication of whether traffic conditions and peak-hour traffic levels are, or would be, sufficient to
justify installation of a traffic signal.

text.b: Signalized Intersection Level of Service Definitions Based on Average Delay

page.text: Source: Transportation Research Board, 2000 Highway Capacity Manual (Washington, D.C., 2000) p10-16.
This level of delay is considered unacceptable by most drivers. This condition
often occurs with oversaturation, that is, when arrival flow rates exceed the
capacity of the intersection. Poor progression and long cycle lengths may also
be major contributing causes of such delay levels.
The influence of congestion becomes more noticeable. Longer delays may
result from some combination of unfavorable signal progression, long cycle
lengths, or high volume-to-capacity (V/C) ratios. Many vehicles stop and
This is considered to be the limit of acceptable delay. These high delay values
generally indicate poor signal progression, long cycle lengths, and high volume-
to-capacity (V/C) ratios. Individual cycle failures occur frequently.
Operations characterized by good signal progression and/or short cycle
lengths. More vehicles stop than with LOS A, causing higher levels of average
Higher delays may result from fair signal progression and/or longer cycle
lengths. Individual cycle failures may begin to appear at this level. The number
of vehicles stopping is significant, though some vehicles may still pass through
Signal progression is extremely favorable. Most vehicles arrive during the
green phase and do not stop at all. Short cycle lengths may also contribute to

text.b: Unsignalized Intersection Level of Service Definitions Based on Delay

page.text: Source: Transportation Research Board, 2000 Highway Capacity Manual (Washington, D.C., 2000) p17-2.

text.b: Traffic Operation Standards and Significant Impact Criteria

page.text: Significance criteria are used to establish what constitutes a project impact. The Town of Atherton has not
formally established minimum acceptable LOS standards or significance criteria for its intersections. The
following significance criteria used in this study are consistent with the criteria applied to Atherton
intersections in other recent traffic studies
A project is said to create a significant impact on traffic conditions at an intersection if, for either peak hour,
any of the following conditions occurs:
1. The level of service at the intersection degrades from LOS D or better under no project conditions to
LOS E or F under project conditions, or
2. The level of service at a signalized intersection is LOS E or F under no project conditions and the
addition of project trips causes the overall average delay to increase by four seconds or more, or
3. The level of service at a two-way stop controlled intersection is LOS E or F under no project
conditions and the addition of project trips causes the delay on the worst approach to increase by 4
Based on the Town of Atherton General Plan (2002), the maximum acceptable average daily traffic (ADT) on
local streets is 1,000 vehicles. On collector streets, the capacity varies between 2,500-12,000 vehicles per
The remainder of this report is divided into six chapters. Chapter 2 describes existing conditions, including the
existing roadway network, transit service, and existing bicycle and pedestrian facilities. Chapter 3 describes
the method used to estimate project traffic, project impacts on the transportation system, and recommended
mitigation measures under existing plus project conditions. Chapter 4 presents the intersection levels of
service under near-term conditions. Chapter 5 identifies project impacts on the transportation system and
recommended mitigation measures under near-term plus project conditions. Chapter 6 presents the analysis
of other transportation related issues, including site access, on-site circulation, and parking.
This chapter describes the existing conditions for all of the major transportation facilities in the vicinity of the
site, including the roadway network, transit service, and bicycle and pedestrian facilities.
Regional access to the project site is provided by a state highway, El Camino Real (SR 82), and a minor
arterial street, Middlefield Road. Local access is provided by two collector streets, Fair Oaks Lane and
Watkins Avenue, and the three local roadways, Ashfield Road, Maple Avenue, and Dinkelspiel Station Lane.
Descriptions of each roadway facility are presented below. For purposes of the transportation analysis, El
Camino Real and all streets parallel to it are defined as north-south roadways, while Fair Oaks Lane and all
streets parallel to it are defined as east-west roadways.
El Camino Real (SR 82) is a north-south State highway, which extends through San Mateo and Santa Clara
Counties. Within the project vicinity it is six lanes wide (three in each direction) with, a raised median, and left-
turn bays. In Atherton, the land uses abutting El Camino Real are mostly residential.
Middlefield Road is a two- to four-lane minor arterial that begins in Downtown Redwood City and extends to
San Antonio Avenue in Mountain View. In the project vicinity, Middlefield Road has two travel lanes (one in
each direction) and bike lanes. Middlefield Road provides access mainly to residential and school areas in the
Fair Oaks Lane is a two-lane collector that extends between Middlefield Road and El Camino Real, where it
intersects opposite and slightly offset from Atherton Avenue. On-street parking is not permitted on Fair Oaks
Lane. The posted speed limit is 25 miles per hour (mph). Fair Oaks Lane provides access to residential areas
Ashfield Road is a two-lane local street that extends between El Camino Real and Dinkelspiel Station Lane.
Ashfield Road provides access to abutting residences and the Civic Center area. Parking is permitted on the
Maple Avenue is a two-lane local street that extends between El Camino Real and Dinkelspiel Station Lane.
Maple Avenue provides access to residences and the Civic Center area. On-street parking is permitted on the
Watkins Avenue is a two-lane collector facility that extends between El Camino Real and Middlefield Road.
On-street parking is not permitted on Watkins Avenue. The posted speed limit is 25 mph. Watkins Avenue
provides access to residences and the Civic Center area via Dinkelspiel Station Lane.
Dinkelspiel Station Lane is a two-lane local street that traverses the Civic Center area to connect Fair Oaks
Lane and Watkins Avenue. Perpendicular and parallel parking for the Civic Center is provided adjacent to
Bicycle facilities are classified in three ways: off-street paths separated from auto traffic (Class I), on-street
striped lanes (Class II), and on-street signed routes in which bicycles share the roadway with other vehicles
(Class III). Currently Class II bicycle lanes are provided along Middlefield Road in the vicinity of the project
site. Figure 4 shows the existing bicycle facilities in the vicinity of the project site. There are no other classified
bicycle facilities on study area roadways. However, as stated in the Town’s General Plan, because of the
scenic nature of the Town of Atherton, most public roadways in the Town are suitable for use by bicyclists.
Pedestrian facilities in the study area include crosswalks and actuated pedestrian signals on the north and
west legs at the El Camino Real/Fair Oaks Lane intersection. There are no sidewalks on any roadways in the
study area. The construction of vertical curbs and sidewalks is prohibited since their presence would be
incongruent with existing development (Town of Atherton General Plan Policy 2.721). However, as stated in
the Town’s General Plan, Atherton’s circulation network is scenic in nature, which makes the public roadways
in the Town attractive to pedestrians.
Local and regional transit service in the Town of Atherton is provided by the San Mateo County Transit District
(SamTrans) and Caltrain. The transit services provided near the study area are summarized below.
SamTrans primarily serves as a local transit provider within San Mateo County, but also provides local and
regional services to neighboring Santa Clara and San Francisco Counties. The existing SamTrans service is
described below and shown on Figure 5.
Route 84 only runs on school days. It provides morning and afternoon service to Hillview and Encinal
Schools. Within the study area, Route 84 operates on El Camino Real, Fair Oaks Lane and Middlefield Road.
The nearest bus stop is located on Fair Oaks Lane just east of McCormick Lane, about 900 feet east of
Route 296 provides weekday and weekend service between the Redwood City Transit Center and East
Bayshore Road/Donohoe Street in East Palo Alto and stops along Middlefield Road in the project vicinity, with
the nearest bus stop on Middlefield Road north of Fair Oaks Lane, approximately one-half mile from the
Route 297 provides weekday and weekend service between the Redwood City Transit Center and the Palo
Alto Transit Center. The route traverses Middlefield Road in the project vicinity, with the nearest bus stop on
Middlefield Road north of Fair Oaks Lane, approximately one-half mile from the Atherton Civic Center.
Route 397 is an express/multi-city route that provides weekday and weekend service between Downtown San
Francisco and the Palo Alto Transit Center. The route runs along Middlefield Road in the project vicinity, with
the nearest bus stop on Middlefield Road north of Fair Oaks Lane, approximately one-half mile from the
Route ECR is an express/multi-city route that provides weekday and weekend service between the Daly City
BART Station and the Palo Alto Transit Center. In the vicinity of the project site, the route runs along El Camino
Real. The nearest bus stop for southbound travel is located on the west side of El Camino Real just south of
Ashfield Road. For northbound travel, the nearest bus stop is located on the east side of El Camino Real just
Caltrain is a regional, intercity commuter rail service between San Francisco and Santa Clara Counties. On
weekdays, service extends between San Francisco and Gilroy, and on weekends, San Jose is the service’s
southern terminus. The Atherton station is located on the east side of Dinkelspiel Station Lane between Fair
Oaks Lane and Ashfield Road. The Atherton Caltrain station is only served on weekends. Currently, there are
16 northbound and 16 southbound Caltrain trains that stop at the Atherton station each Saturday and 14
northbound and 14 southbound Caltrain trains that stop at the Atherton station each Sunday.

text.b: Intersection Lane Configurations and Traffic Volumes

page.text: The existing lane configurations at the study intersections were obtained from field observations (see Figure
6). Existing intersection traffic volumes at five of the study intersections are based on traffic counts conducted
in September, 2013 and were obtained from the Existing Conditions memorandum report for the Civic Center
Master Plan (W-Trans, November 7, 2013) New manual peak-hour turning-movement counts were conducted
at the remaining two study intersections in November 2014 (see Figure 7). The intersection counts include
vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians during the morning peak period (7:00-9:00 AM) and afternoon peak period
(5:00-7:00 PM). The new intersection counts are included in Appendix A.
Table 3 shows the results of the intersection level of service analysis under existing conditions. The level of
service calculation sheets are included in Appendix B. Under existing conditions, the following study
intersections are expected to operate at a poor level of service:
El Camino Real and Ashfield Road: LOS F on both stop-controlled approaches (eastbound and
westbound) in both AM and PM peak hours.
El Camino Real and Maple Avenue: LOS F on the eastbound stop-controlled approach in the AM
peak hour and the westbound stop-controlled approach in the PM peak hour.

Overall weighted average control delay (seconds per vehicle) is reported for signalized intersections.
Worst stop-controlled approach delay (seconds per vehicle) is reported for two-way stop-controlled intersections.
Bold indicates a poor level of service (LOS E or F).
Existing roadway segment traffic volumes for study segments on Fair Oaks Lane and Ashfield Road were
obtained from mechanical tube counts conducted on in September, 2013. The tube count data are included in
Appendix A. Tube counts were conducted on the Maple Avenue study segment in November, 2014. Roadway
segment operation for the study segments are summarized in Table 4. The existing traffic volumes on all
study roadway segments are within the typical volume ranges expressed in the Town of Atherton General
El Camino Real - Dinkelspiel Station Lane Collector
El Camino Real - Dinkelspiel Station Lane Local Street
El Camino Real - Dinkelspiel Station Lane Local Street
This chapter describes existing plus project traffic conditions, including the method by which project traffic is
estimated. Existing plus project conditions include the addition of traffic expected to be generated by the
Civic Center Master Plan project. Existing plus project traffic conditions could potentially occur if the Civic
Center Master Plan project was completed prior to the other approved projects in the surrounding cities. It is
unlikely that this traffic condition would occur, since other approved projects expected to add traffic to the
study area would likely be built and occupied during the time the project is going through the environmental
The Master Plan project would reconfigure Ashfield Road and Dinkelspiel Station Lane around the new Civic
Center. As shown on Figure 3, Dinkelspiel Station Lane would no longer connect directly to Fair Oaks Lane.
Instead, Dinkelspiel Station Lane would terminate at Ashfield Road, which would be realigned and extended
to intersect with Fair Oaks Lane directly opposite from Fair Oaks Court. The intersection of Fair Oaks Lane
and Ashfield Road would be stop controlled on the north (Fair Oaks Court) and south (Ashfield Road)
The proposed change in the roadway network would eliminate the Dinkelspiel Station Lane/Fair Oaks Lane
intersection, and thus the existing stop sign on eastbound Fair Oaks Lane at Dinkelspiel Station Lane could
be eliminated. However, due to the restricted sight distance at the Fair Oaks/Lloyden intersection, it is
recommended that the existing stop sign on eastbound Fair Oaks Lane be moved from its current location at
Dinkelspiel Station to the eastbound Fair Oaks approach at Lloyden Drive. The existing roadway curve
combined with the fence and landscaping on the adjacent property hinders the ability of drivers on Lloyden
Drive to see traffic on eastbound Fair Oaks. Adequate visibility exists from Lloyden Drive to see traffic
approaching on westbound Fair Oaks Lane so that approach could continue to operate without any control.
With the recommended stop control on the eastbound approach, traffic stopped on southbound Lloyden Drive
would be able to see all opposing traffic in both directions before proceeding.
It is assumed that the transportation network and geometry for all other study intersections and roadway
segments under existing plus project conditions would be the same as the existing transportation network.
The magnitude of traffic produced by the Atherton Civic Center and the locations where that traffic would
appear are estimated using a three-step process: (1) trip generation, (2) trip distribution, and (3) trip
assignment. In determining project trip generation, the magnitude of traffic entering and exiting the site is
estimated for the AM and PM peak hours. As part of the project trip distribution, an estimate is made of the
directions to and from which the project trips would travel. In the project trip assignment, the project trips are
assigned to specific streets. These procedures are described further in the following sections.
The new Civic Center would result in an increase in library and administrative building space. However, the
Town is not expected to increase administrative staff in the future or provide new administrative services at
the Civic Center. Therefore, the trip generation associated with the administrative uses at the new Civic
Center (including the Town Administration, Building, Planning, Police, and Public Works Departments) are
expected to be the same as under existing conditions. Thus, the net new project trips reflect an increase only
in library trips resulting from an increase in library space from 5,058 square feet under existing conditions to
the proposed 9,000 square feet. The additional building space will enable the library to increase their
collection and provide additional services not present at the existing library. Furthermore, the proposed library
may generate traffic at a higher rate per square foot than the existing library due to the attractiveness of the
A trip generation survey was conducted on Wednesday, November 12, 2014 to quantify the trips generated
by the existing library. Survey staff observed vehicles traveling to and from the Civic Center area to
differentiate library traffic from traffic associated with other Civic Center uses. Currently, the library is open
from 10:00 AM to 8:00 PM Monday through Wednesday, from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM on Thursday and Friday,
from 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM on Saturday, and from 1:00 AM to 5:00 PM on Sunday. Thus, the library is not
open during the peak morning commute hours. However, a book drop is available at all hours. The library
book drop did not generate any trips during the AM peak hour on the day of the survey. During the PM peak
hour, the existing library generated 11 vehicle trips (4 inbound and 7 outbound). The observed trip rates are
less than the average library trip rates published in the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip
Edition. To be conservative, the trips generated by the new library were estimated using the
ITE library trip rates. Trips generated by the existing library were subtracted from the trip estimates for the
proposed library to estimate the net new project trips (see Table 5). After applying the trip credit, the proposed
library is estimated to generate a net increase of 421 daily vehicle trips including 9 AM peak-hour trips (6
inbound and 3 outbound) and 55 PM peak-hour trips (28 inbound and 27 outbound).
Daily and peak hour trip generation are based on trip generation rates published in ITE Trip Generation, 9th Edition (Land Use
Peak hour trips are based on a trip generation survey conducted at the existing library on Wednesday, November 12, 2014. Daily
trips are estimated based on the ratio of daily to PM peak hour trips published in ITE Trip Generation, 9th Edition (Land Use #590).
The trip distribution pattern for the proposed library was estimated based on the Atherton library service area,
the locations of other public libraries in neighboring communities, including East Palo Alto, Palo Alto, Menlo
Park, and Redwood City, and existing travel patterns in the study area. The assumed library trip distribution
pattern is shown on Figure 8. The net peak-hour trips generated by the project were assigned to the roadway
system in accordance with the trip distribution pattern. Figure 9 shows the assignment of project trips at each
Additionally, the Master Plan would reconfigure the roadways through the Civic Center such that Dinkelspiel
Station Lane would no longer intersect with Fair Oaks Lane. Instead it would terminate at Ashfield Road,
which would be extended and realigned to intersect Fair Oaks Lane directly opposite Fair Oaks Court. Under
the new configuration, vehicles that currently access the Civic Center via the Dinkelspiel Station Lane/Fair
Oaks Lane intersection would instead access the new Civic Center via the Ashfield Road/Fair Oaks Lane
intersection. In addition, some of the existing trips that currently access the library via Ashfield Road would
likely shift to Maple Avenue. Figure 10 shows the reassignment of existing Civic Center traffic expected as a
result of the proposed changes in the roadway network.
The project trips and reassigned existing trips, as represented in the above project trip assignment, were
added to existing traffic volumes to obtain existing plus project traffic volumes. The existing plus project traffic
The results of the intersection level of service analysis under existing plus project conditions are summarized
in Table 6. The intersection level of service calculation sheets are included in Appendix B. The results show
that under existing plus project conditions, the following study intersections are expected to operate at a poor
El Camino Real and Ashfield Road: LOS F on both stop-controlled approaches (eastbound and
westbound) in both the AM and PM peak hours.
El Camino Real and Maple Avenue: LOS F on the eastbound stop-controlled approach in the AM
peak hour and the westbound stop-controlled approach in the PM peak hour.
The remaining study intersections are expected to operate at LOS C or better during both the AM and PM
Traffic signal warrants were checked for the El Camino Real/Ashfield Road and El Camino Real/Maple
Avenue intersections. This assessment was made on the basis of the peak-hour volume signal warrant,
Warrant #3 described in the California MUTCD. This method makes no evaluation of intersection level of
service, but simply provides an indication whether peak-hour traffic volumes are, or would be, sufficient to
justify installation of a traffic signal. The analysis shows that the peak-hour volume warrant would not be
satisfied at the El Camino Real/Ashfield Road or El Camino Real/Maple Avenue intersections under existing
conditions or existing plus project conditions. Thus, signalization of these study intersections is not
At the El Camino Real/Ashfield Road intersection, the project is expected to cause a slight decrease in traffic
volume because some of the existing trips that currently access the library via Ashfield Road would likely shift
to Maple Avenue. As a result, the project would reduce the delay on the worst stop-controlled approach
(westbound) during the PM peak hour. There would be no change in delay on the eastbound approach during
the PM peak hour. Likewise, the project would have no effect on the delay experienced at this intersection
during the AM peak hour. Therefore, the project impact on traffic operations at this intersection would be less
At the El Camino Real/Maple Avenue intersection, the project is expected to add one trip in the AM peak hour
and 8 trips in the PM peak hour to the westbound left-turn movement from Maple Avenue to southbound El
Camino Real. Field observations and the intersection level of service analysis show that the heavy volume of
traffic on El Camino Real leaves few gaps in traffic large enough to accommodate left turns from the stop-
controlled Maple Avenue approaches. As a result, the small increase in traffic associated with the project
would cause the average delay on the westbound stop-controlled approach to increase by more than four
seconds during the PM peak hour. Therefore, the project is considered to have a significant impact at this
intersection. The impact could be satisfactorily mitigated by implementation of one or both of the following
Prohibit Left Turns. The Town of Atherton may choose to prohibit left turns from westbound Maple
Avenue to southbound El Camino Real. With the turn restriction, the westbound stop-controlled
approach would operate at LOS B during the PM peak hour. The turn restriction could be put in effect
only during certain hours (e.g. 5:00 – 7:00 PM ) through appropriate signage or all day by signage
and a raised median that would physically prevent left-turns and through movements from Maple
Avenue. Restricting left turns only during peak hours would retain full access during other times when
traffic volumes and delay are lower. However, it would be difficult to enforce the part-time turn
restriction since there would not be a physical barrier preventing vehicles from turning left. Also, it
should be noted that the Town’s General Plan states that street lights and signs shall be kept to a
minimum (Policy 2.426). Therefore, the Town may choose to consider alternative mitigation
Public Education. While the traffic analysis assumes that trips to and from the Civic Center uses will
travel via the most direct routes, it is likely that many Civic Center drivers seeking to head south on El
Camino Real may choose to travel through the signalized Fair Oaks/El Camino intersection in order
to avoid the difficulty of turning left onto El Camino Real from Maple Avenue based on prior
experience at this location or other unsignalized intersections on El Camino Real. The self-selection
of Fair Oaks Avenue may reduce the project impact at the Maple/El Camino intersection below that
shown in Table 6. The Town of Atherton may further reduce the project’s impact at the Maple/El
Camino intersection through the use of a public education campaign to advise motorists traveling
between the Civic Center and El Camino Real to use Fair Oaks Lane. Notices may be sent to local
residents on Maple Avenue and Civic Center employees, and posted for public view at various
locations within the Civic Center including the Atherton Library.

Trips are rounded to to the nearest 10.
The Master Plan project is expected to result in a modest increase in traffic (less than 200 vehicles per day)
on selected street segments. The traffic volumes on all of the study roadways would continue to be within the
typical volume ranges stated in the Town’s General Plan.
This chapter describes near-term traffic conditions, which reflect future traffic volumes on the existing
roadway network. Near-term traffic volumes reflect traffic generated by approved but not yet constructed
developments in the vicinity of the project site. This chapter describes the procedure used to determine near-
term traffic volumes and the resulting traffic conditions.
It is assumed in this analysis that the transportation network under near-term conditions would be the same
Approved and pending developments are those developments that have been approved by local agencies or
are built but not yet occupied. Traffic from these projects was added to the local study area network. Project
lists were requested from the Town of Atherton, the Cities of Menlo Park, Palo Alto, and Redwood City, and
San Mateo County. The following approved developments are expected to add trips to study area roadways
and were included in the near-term conditions:
1706 El Camino Real: 10,148 square feet of medical / dental office use in Menlo Park
1300 El Camino Real: 110,065 square feet of office / commercial space in Menlo Park
1460 El Camino Real: 26,800-square-foot office building and 16-unit townhouse in Menlo Park
Stanford in Redwood City Precise Plan: 1,518,000 square feet of new space in approximately 13 new
2550 El Camino Real: 11,100 square feet of retail art supply in Redwood City
2580 El Camino Real: 141-unit apartments in Redwood City
2808 El Camino Real: 45-bed assisted living facility in Redwood City
Near-term peak-hour traffic volumes were calculated by adding to existing volumes the estimated traffic from
the approved developments. Vehicle trips from the approved projects were obtained from the project’s traffic
impact study, if available. For projects without a traffic impact report, trip estimates were developed using
rates published in the ITE Trip Generation Manual, 9
Edition. The estimated trips were assigned to the study
intersections according to distributions identified in the development traffic studies, if available, or knowledge
of the study area. Near-term traffic volumes are shown on Figure 12.
Table 8 shows the results of the intersection level of service analysis under near-term conditions. The level of
service calculation sheets are included in Appendix B. Under near-term conditions, the following study
intersections are expected to operate worse than acceptable jurisdictional standards:
El Camino Real and Ashfield Road: LOS F on the stop-controlled approaches (eastbound and west
bound) in both AM and PM peak hours.
El Camino Real and Maple Avenue: LOS F on the eastbound stop-controlled approach in AM peak
hour and the westbound stop-controlled approach in PM peak hour.

This chapter describes near-term traffic conditions that would occur when the project is complete. Near-term
plus project conditions were evaluated relative to near-term conditions in order to determine potential project
impacts. This traffic scenario represents a more congested traffic condition than the existing plus project
scenario, since it includes traffic generated by approved but not yet built or occupied developments in the
The transportation network under near-term plus project conditions, including roadways and intersection lane
configurations, would be the same as that described under existing plus project conditions (Chapter 3).
Net new trips generated by the project and the re-assigned exiting trips as a result of the project would be the
same as that described under existing plus project conditions (Chapter 3).
The peak-hour trips generated by the project were added to near-term traffic volumes (described in Chapter
4) to obtain near-term plus project traffic volumes. The near-term plus project traffic volumes are shown on
The results of the intersection level of service analysis under near-term plus project conditions are
summarized in Table 10. The intersection level of service calculation sheets are included in Appendix B. The
results show that under near-term plus project conditions, the following study intersections are expected to
operate at a poor level of service:
El Camino Real and Ashfield Road: LOS F on both stop-controlled approaches (eastbound and
westbound) in both the AM and PM peak hours.
El Camino Real and Maple Avenue: LOS F on the eastbound stop-controlled approach in the AM
peak hour and the westbound stop-controlled approach in the PM peak hour.
The remaining study intersections are expected to operate at LOS C or better during both the AM and PM
Traffic signal warrants were checked for the El Camino Real/Ashfield Road and El Camino Real/Maple
Avenue intersections. This assessment was made on the basis of the peak-hour volume signal warrant,
Warrant #3 described in the California MUTCD. This method makes no evaluation of intersection level of
service, but simply provides an indication whether peak-hour traffic volumes would justify installation of a
traffic signal. The analysis shows that the peak-hour volume warrant would not be satisfied at the El Camino
Real/Ashfield Road or El Camino Real/Maple Avenue intersections under near-term or near-term plus project
conditions. Thus, signalization of these study intersections is not recommended.
The project is expected to cause a slight decrease in traffic volume at the intersection of El Camino Real and
Ashfield Road resulting in a reduction in the delay for the worst stop-controlled approach (westbound) during
the PM peak hour. There would be no change in delay on the eastbound approach during the PM peak hour.
Likewise, the project would have no effect on the delay experienced at this intersection during the AM peak
hour. Therefore, the project impact on traffic operations at this intersection would be less than significant.
Although the project would add very few trips to the El Camino Real/Maple Avenue intersection, the heavy
volume of traffic on El Camino Real makes turn movements from stop-controlled side streets difficult. As a
result, the small increase in traffic associated with the project would cause the average delay on the
westbound stop-controlled approach to increase by more than four seconds during the PM peak hour.
Therefore, the project is considered to have a significant impact at this intersection. The impact could be
satisfactorily mitigated by implementation of one or both of the mitigation measures identified in Chapter 3.

Increase/decrease in daily trips on the subject roadway including additional trips generated by the new library and reassigned existing trips.

This chapter presents an analysis of other transportation issues associated with the project, including:
Potential impacts to bicycles, pedestrians, and transit facilities
The project would reconfigure the Civic Center circulation network to safely accommodate all transportation
modes. In addition to the local street network, the Civic Center would include a network of fully accessible
paths for pedestrians and bicyclists. The network would also link existing and proposed open spaces to
existing buildings, such as the Town Hall and Caltrain Station.
As shown in the Master Plan, Dinkelspiel Station Lane would remain the main north/south connection through
the Civic Center area linking Fair Oaks Lane to the north and Maple Street to the south. Additionally, Ashfield
Road would continue to function as the western gateway connecting to both El Camino Real and Fair Oaks
Lane. Near the northern edge of the site, Dinkelspiel Station Lane would curve to the west and intersect with
Ashfield Road just south of Fair Oaks Lane. Two-way stop control is recommended with a stop sign on
Dinkelspiel Station Lane and no control on Ashfield Road. Although this intersection would be only about 60
feet south of the Fair Oaks/Ashfield intersection, the traffic volumes on Ashfield Road are projected to remain
rather low such that, except for very rare occurrences, no more than a single vehicle would be stopped at
either intersection. Therefore, traffic is not expected to back up from one intersection through the next.
Ninety-degree parking spaces are proposed at various locations along Dinkelspiel Station Lane and Ashfield
Road. The traffic volumes and vehicle speeds on these streets are expected to be low such that parking
maneuvers would not pose a hazard or significantly disrupt traffic. In addition, a small off-street parking area
is shown immediately north of the proposed Town Administration Building. This lot would have 90-degree
parking on both sides of a dead end aisle. There appears to be sufficient space at the end of the parking aisle
to allow vehicles to turn around when the lot is full. Since it would be difficult to determine if any spaces were
available before turning into the lot, it is recommended that these spaces be reserved for staff parking.
The Civic Center Master Plan contains conceptual level drawings that lack the detail required for a thorough
review of specific design features. In order to provide a circulation network that would safely accommodate
automobiles, pedestrians, and bicyclists, it’s recommended that the final design incorporate the following
Maintain minimum roadway pavement width to reduce vehicle travel speeds within the project site.
Provide adequate sight distance at intersections and roadway curves within the Civic Center area to
ensure safe access for all travel modes.
Provide adequate lighting along pedestrian/bicycle paths within the Civic Center area.
Street widths and radii of curvature should allow for the movement of garbage trucks, delivery
vehicles, fire trucks and other emergency vehicles.

text.b: Potential Impacts on Bicycle, Pedestrian, and Transit Facilities

page.text: As stated in the Town’s General Plan, most public roadways in the Town are suitable for use by bicyclists and
pedestrians. Additionally, the project would provide a circulation network to safely accommodate all
transportation modes, including bicycle and pedestrian travel within the Civic Center area. Therefore,
although the new library may increase bicyclists and pedestrians accessing the Civic Center, they should be
able to ride/walk on access streets in the project vicinity without major safety concerns. For streets within the
Civic Center area, implementation of the recommendations listed in the previous section will ensure safe on-
site circulation for bicyclists and pedestrians.
The Town of Atherton’s Pedestrian and Bicycle Master Plan, adopted in November 2014, shows that several
streets within the study area, including Fair Oaks Lane, Watkins Avenue, and Dinkelspiel Station Lane, are to
be designated as Class III bike routes. Because the project would reconfigure Dinkelspiel Station Lane
through the Civic Center, the roadway design should implement the recommended bike route along
Dinkelspiel Station Lane with appropriate cross-section design, signage, and pavement markings to ensure
consistency with the Pedestrian and Bicycle Master Plan.
The proposed Civic Center would continue to be served by the existing SamTrans bus routes and Caltrain.
No change in service is expected as a result of the project. The project is expected to have an insignificant
impact on the existing transit ridership levels.
The existing Civic Center includes approximately 210 parking spaces, including 96 spaces at the Atherton
Caltrain Station, 52 spaces for the Administration Building/Police/Post Office, 20 spaces for the Permit
Center, 9 spaces in the Public Works Corporation Yard, and 33 spaces for the Library. The Master Plan
project would reduce the parking supply by approximately 91 spaces leaving a total of 119 spaces at buildout,
including 33 spaces for Caltrain parking, 63 spaces for Civic Center uses, 19 spaces for secure police
parking, and 4 spaces in the Public Works Corporation Yard.
In order to estimate the parking demand for the new Civic Center, a parking occupancy survey was conducted
to quantify the parking demand generated by the existing Civic Center uses. The survey was conducted
between the 8 AM and 9 PM on a typical weekday (Wednesday, November 12, 2014) and between 10 AM to
6 PM on a typical Saturday (November 15, 2014). The result of the survey is included in Appendix C and
summarized in Table 12. The maximum parking demand observed was 63 vehicles on a weekday and 49
vehicles on a Saturday. For the library, the maximum parking demand observed was 13 vehicles on the
weekday and 26 vehicles on the Saturday, when there was a presentation held during the survey period.
Total parking demand did not include the corporation yard because it was locked and inaccessible on Saturday.
Bold indicates the maximum occupied parking spaces.
Source: Parking occupancy surveys conducted by Hexagon Transportation Consultants on 11/12/14 and 11/15/14.
The Town is not expected to increase administrative employees in the future or provide new administrative
services at the Civic Center. Therefore, the parking demand for these uses is expected to remain unchanged.
The new library is the only use that may generate an increase in parking demand above the current parking
Parking generation rates published in ITE Parking Generation were compared to the actual parking demand
observed at the existing Atherton library. The ITE average parking generation rates for a library are 2.61
vehicles per 1,000 square feet on a typical weekday and 2.27 vehicles per 1,000 square feet on a typical
weekend. The observed weekday parking generation rate (2.57 vehicles per 1,000 square feet) is very close
to the ITE average rate (2.61). However, the parking generation rate observed on Saturday (4.15 vehicles per
1,000 square feet) is 83 percent higher than the ITE parking generation rate (2.27). To be conservative, the
higher of the two rates in each case was used to estimate the future parking demand generated by the new
Since Caltrain service at the Atherton station is currently limited to weekends only, the Caltrain parking
spaces are mostly unused. However, the planned Caltrain Electrification Project would reintroduce weekday
service with 54 trains projected to stop in Atherton each day. With the Electrification Project, it is estimated
that Caltrain riders would occupy as many as 28 parking spaces at the Atherton Civic Center in the year 2020
(Peninsula Corridor Electrification Project EIR, February 2014). The dedicated Caltrain parking proposed in
the Civic Center Master Plan (33 spaces) would be adequate to accommodate the projected ridership at the
The estimated total parking demand for the proposed Civic Center is shown in Table 13. With the project, the
maximum parking demand would be 95 vehicles on weekdays and 86 vehicles on weekends, which is lower
than the proposed parking supply of 119 spaces. Therefore, the project would provide a sufficient parking
supply to meet the projected overall demand. However, it should be noted that the project proposes only 4
parking spaces for the Public Works Corporation Yard while the parking occupancy survey showed as many
as 7 vehicles parked in the Corporation Yard on a weekday. Any parking overflow in this area could be
accommodated by the unassigned Civic Center parking stalls.

text.b: Proposed Civic Center Parking Demand Estimates

page.text: Based on the peak parking demand observed on site on 11/12/14 and 11/15/14.
Weekday parking demand is estimated based on the parking generation rate published in ITE
Parking Generation, 4th Edition (Land Use Code 590). Weekend parking demand is estimated
based on the parking generation rate observed at the existing library.
Caltrain 2020 parking demand estimate was obtained from the Peninsula Corridor Electrification
